name: Campaign
label: Campaign Builder
instructions: Use this form to expand an idea into a playable RPG campaign.

fields.name: changes
fields.label: Changes
fields.instructions: What changes are happening in the world?

fields.name: mood
fields.label: Mood
fields.instructions: Grim, exciting, zany, lyrical, tactical, dream-like, happy, sad, desperate, exuberant, etc. How will the players feel?

fields.name: visual_style
fields.label: Visual Style
fields.instructions: How do you see it in your mind? Does it look like a favorite movie, comic, artist, etc.?

fields.name: scope
fields.label: Scope
fields.instructions: A city, a planet, a war, a subculture, etc.

fields.name: end
fields.label: End
fields.instructions: Does this scenario have an end?

fields.name: driver
fields.label: Drivers
fields.instructions: These are pattens for writing playable adventures. Pick some and describe how they work in this case.

hints.label: Agents
hints.description: PCs work for someone who sends them on adventures. James Bond works for MI6. Rebels work for the Rebel Alliance. Brave knights work for their king. Indian Jones works for the archeology department at Marshall College. PCs can be an elite team. Or they might work in an obscure corner of some vast bureaucracy. And the varieties of jobs are endless. Consider The X-Files, Men in Black, Stargate, Sanctuary, Outland, Judge Dee, Agents of Shield, Battlestar Galactica, all the Star Treks, The Avengers, Blade Runner, Mission Impossible, and Torchwood.

hints.label: Freelancers
hints.description:
Paid freelancers include Ghostbusters(tm), private detectives, bodyguards, bounty hunters, assassins, hackers, mercenaries, etc. PCs can be guns for hire, swords for hire, spells for hire, cyberdecks for hire, or have fast ships, or other vehicles, for hire.

The PCs are contacted by their customers, and paid to go on adventures.

hints.label: Privateers
hints.description:
Privateers were like pirates who operated during a war. They had permission from their side to attack and rob ships belonging to the other side.

In many fantasy RPGs, parties of humans, elves, are allowed to hunt down members of an "enemy" species and take their stuff.

Robin Hood was technically a bandit. But occupiers and oppressors can excuse plenty of fun and profitable crime.

hints.label: Quest
hints.description: A journey to achieve a goal. The advantage is a single crystal clear goal. Quests may seek a magical treasure, a cure, or a personal fortune. The Lord of the Rings trilogy is a quest to destroy the ring. Battlestar Galactica is a quest for the legendary lost colony and a new home.

hints.label: Survival
hints.description:
PCs may be lost or marooned away from their own kind, trying to stay alive and find a way home. Castaways can be transported by fantastic means and can find themselves in very strange places. Examples: John Carter of Mars Lost in Space, and Farscape. A large group of castaways might turn into a colony. And exiles are deliberate castaways.

Or PCs might man a lonely outpost in a dangerous land, or simply try to stay a live in a deadly, futuristic urban wasteland. PCs might be hated, hunted, or tracked by a relentless foe. Survival might also depend on meeting a special need, such as a vampire's need for blood.

Survivors explore their environment, fight off attackers, and seek vital resources. They meet new friends and allies, and new enemies.

hints.label: Personal Mission
hints.description:
Or "personal quest". The PCs are doing something because they just really want to do it, or because they deeply believe it should be done.

They are driven to become the worlds greatest swordsman, to advance science, prove the Hollow Earth is real, or bring back Atlantis. A PC's personal mission might also be an extended hunt or mystery.

A PC with a personal quest and a personal fortune can employ like-minded PCs in Jobs With Missions.

hints.label: Escape
hints.description: A kind of Quest. A desperate journey to Anywhere Else. Powerful, but best for short campaigns.

hints.label: Merchants
hints.description: business isn't always boring. Think of the early spice traders in Earth’s Age of Exploration, the caravans along the Silk Road, or maybe the fur traders of the American frontier.

hints.label: Keys Quest
hints.description:
A classic… The Great Magic Thing was divided into parts. The parts were scattered and hidden in dangerous places. And the PCs have a reason to find them.

Like all quests, it has a final end. But it has a bunch of intermediate ends, too. Twelve parts automatically gives you twelve adventures. Stretch it to a few adventures per part and you can get a whole year of play.

It’s over-used. But it’s over-used because it works.

hints.label: Wandering Heroes
hints.description:
PCs have explicitly signed up to fight evil and help those in need. Examples: Knights of the Round Table, Dr. Who, The A-Team.

This is a popular classic. But make sure the players explicitly agree to it, because it requires the PCs to do dangerous things without any other rational motivation.

hints.label: Treasure Hunters
hints.description:
Treasure hunting is popular in fiction and a straightforward source of adventures.

However, treasure hunters who are after the Big Score either get tired of failing, or succeed and retire. So don't count on treasure hunting alone for a long campaign.

fields.name: toy
fields.label: Toys and Treasures
fields.instructions: Things the players will love using. Common categories include...

fields.name: place
fields.label: Places
fields.instructions: Describe some places where the action happens.

fields.name: side
fields.label: Sides
fields.instructions: Groups or important individuals, or dragons or gods, etc. These can be outright foes, or anyone with interests different enough that you might have to negotiate with them.

fields.name: example_pcs
fields.label: Some example PCs...
fields.instructions: Write a few lines about some PCs you might enjoy playing.

fields.name: adventure
fields.label: Adventures
fields.instructions: How can you run some of these classic adventure types?

hints.label: Assault
hints.description: Attack a place to achieve a goal. Often there's a planning an preparation phase, followed by sneaking and/or combat, sometimes followed by running away.

hints.label: Siege
hints.description: Defend a place, and maybe some NPCs, a valuable location, etc. Common phases are discovering the threat,  finding and reaching the refuge, preparing defenses, and multiple waves of attacks with recovery and repair in between. PCs might be rescued by sunrise or the cavalry. Or they might weaken their foes enough to make a run for it, or even just win outright.

hints.label: Recon
hints.description: Go somewhere dangerous. Gather information to help plan future action. Get out alive.

hints.label: Rescue
hints.description: Get a person or people (or creatures) safely away from people (or creatures) who are holding them prisoner. The people you rescue might be weak or strong, helpful or difficult.

hints.label: Theft
hints.description: Get a thing from the other side, without necessarily having to fight them.

hints.label: Escape
hints.description: PCs have been captured. Most of their equipment has been taken away. And now they try to get away. Escapes can be a nice change of pace where the PCs concentrate on getting out of a place instead of getting in. Other adventures can turn into escapes if the PCs are captured. And a successful escape can double as a recon or an all out assault from within.

hints.label: Gauntlet
hints.description: The PCs have to get from point A to point B, possibly while transporting something or someone. And lots of nasties will try to stop them. A gauntlet adventure usually has a linear form, and a clear goal. The pace is fast because the PCs will lose if the enemy has time to organize and concentrate its forces. The theme is overwhelming odds... just not faced all at once. :-)

hints.label: Hunt
hints.description: The PCs track/stalk/chase something that (initially) hides and runs away. The hunt can be literal or metaphorical. And the tables might be turned. But the PCs are generally the pursuers. The PCs can themselves be hunted. But this is harder to run and works best when combined with other adventure types.

hints.label: Monster Mystery
hints.description: Bad things are happening. Investigate. Find the monster. Deal with it.

hints.label: Mystery
hints.description: As in mystery fiction. Sherlock Holmes, etc. PCs are detectives who investigate and solve the mystery.

hints.label: Explore
hints.description: Visit all the parts of a dangerous place to find out what's there. Classic dungeon crawling is Treasure Hunters and Privateers Exploring an underground setting.

hints.label: Capture
hints.description: A Hunt in which someone or something must be taken alive. This is often more complicated than just killing them.

hints.label: Trick
hints.description: And elaborate deception or "con". The PCs must design, prepare, and execute all the parts of a plan. Each step is played out under that constant threat of being discovered. And the PCs might have to improvise if something unexpected happens.

hints.label: Negotiate
hints.description: The PCs must identify, locate, contact, and talk to multiple parties to achieve their goal. Combat isn't the point. But threats are a common tactic. And negotiations might break down.

hints.label: Compete
hints.description: You can add a competitor to other kinds of adventures. Or build the adventure around competition for some otherwise straightforward goal.

fields.name: character_class
fields.label: Character Classes
fields.instructions: Types of people in this world, who they are, and what they do. The rules don't have to be class based. Classes are just an awesome way to tell players about a world.

fields.name: pc_creation_notes
fields.label: PC Creation Notes
fields.instructions: Tell the players who they are, and who they can be.

fields.name: first_adventure
fields.label: First Adventures
fields.instructions: Sketch some adventures to draw the player into the world.
